G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs, thereby conferring subject matter jurisdiction on the Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 3.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Hampden County under G.L. c. 223, § 1 and G.L. c. 223, § 2 because the causes of action arose in Hampden County and the parties reside there.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Hampden County under G.L. c. 223, § 1 and G.L. c. 223, § 2 because the causes of action arose in Hampden County and the parties reside there.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid creating an unreasonable risk of harm to others and their property.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20131.raw_text: Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146–150 (2006) (duty to exercise reasonable care in securing dangerous instrumentalities)
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20131.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid creating an unreasonable risk of harm to others and their property.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20131.support_reasoning: The court expressly states a general Massachusetts tort principle that every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others, grounded in foreseeability of risk. While the case applies this specifically to the storage of firearms as dangerous instrumentalities, the court’s articulation of the general duty rule squarely supports the proposition that Massachusetts law imposes a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid creating an unreasonable risk of harm to others and their property.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20131.relevant_excerpt: "We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ See Remy v. MacDonald, supra at 677, citing Restatement (Second) Torts § 302 comment a (1965). A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor. ... Consequently, with some important exceptions, ‘a defendant owes a duty of care to all persons who are foreseeably endangered by his conduct, with respect to all risks which make the conduct unreasonably dangerous.’"}

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.raw_text: Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739, 743 (1995) (general duty of reasonable care)
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid creating an unreasonable risk of harm to others and their property.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses negligence in terms of the existence of a legal duty and breach, and it reiterates that landowners and possessors must exercise reasonable care not to create unreasonable risks of harm to others, including travelers on adjacent highways. While the case ultimately finds no duty to alter the state highway under these facts, it affirms the general Massachusetts principle that one must exercise reasonable care to avoid creating unreasonable risks of harm to others and their property.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.relevant_excerpt: Before liability for negligence can be imposed, there must first be a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, and a breach of that duty proximately resulting in the injury. ... It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. ... Although a landowner or possessor typically is not held to any duty with respect to public highways adjacent to or crossing his land, he must exercise reasonable care in the use of his land so as not to injure a traveler on the highway.

Remy v. MacDonald, 440 Mass. 675, 677\u2.raw_text: Remy v. MacDonald, 440 Mass. 675, 677–78 (2004) (duty arises from reasonable foreseeability of harm)
Remy v. MacDonald, 440 Mass. 675, 677\u2.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care in the ownership, storage, and control of his personal property—including the Ladder—on and near the shared driveway at 123 Maple Street so as not to create an unreasonable risk of harm to Plaintiff or her property.
Remy v. MacDonald, 440 Mass. 675, 677\u2.support_reasoning: The case discusses the general concept of duty in negligence and notes that, as a general principle, actors owe a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others. However, it does so in the very different context of whether a pregnant mother owes a duty to her unborn child, and ultimately holds that no such duty exists in that context. It does not address or establish a specific duty concerning ownership, storage, or control of personal property near a shared driveway, so it does not substantively support the particular duty proposition asserted.
Remy v. MacDonald, 440 Mass. 675, 677\u2.relevant_excerpt: “In order to succeed on a claim of negligence, a plaintiff first must establish that the defendant owed a legal duty of care. … As a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 302 comment a (1965) (‘In general, anyone who does an affirmative act is under a duty to others to exercise the care of a reasonable man to protect them against an unreasonable risk of harm to them arising out of the act’).”

Luoni v. Berube, 431 Mass. 729, 731\u201.raw_text: Luoni v. Berube, 431 Mass. 729, 731–32 (2000) (duty of reasonable care under all the circumstances of the case)
Luoni v. Berube, 431 Mass. 729, 731\u201.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care in the ownership, storage, and control of his personal property—including the Ladder—on and near the shared driveway at 123 Maple Street so as not to create an unreasonable risk of harm to Plaintiff or her property.
Luoni v. Berube, 431 Mass. 729, 731\u201.support_reasoning: The case recognizes a general landowner duty to act reasonably in maintaining property, but it expressly limits that duty to preexisting physical conditions of the premises and rejects extending it to dangerous items or acts introduced and controlled by third parties. The court emphasizes that a homeowner/social host has no duty to control third-party conduct or chattels the host did not provide or control, which undercuts the claimed proposition that Defendant owed a duty regarding ownership, storage, and control of his personal property (the ladder) on a shared driveway. Thus, Luoni does not affirm the specific duty asserted and in fact narrows it in analogous contexts.
Luoni v. Berube, 431 Mass. 729, 731\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The duty of a landowner under general principles of common-law negligence governing dangerous conditions on his land is established. ‘A landowner must act as a reasonable [person] in maintaining…property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … The obligation to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition refers to preexisting physical conditions… There is no room in this branch of tort law for the plaintiff’s contention that the fireworks somehow constituted a physical condition on the defendants’ land…”

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 153.raw_text: Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 153–54 (2013) (duty based on control and foreseeability of harm)
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 153.proposition: Defendant further owed Plaintiff a duty, as a neighbor and co-occupant of the premises sharing a common driveway, to exercise reasonable care in maintaining conditions immediately adjacent to the shared driveway in a reasonably safe condition for foreseeable use by Plaintiff.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 153.support_reasoning: The case concerns a landlord’s duty as a landowner to remedy an open and obvious danger on property he controls, based on foreseeability of harm to a lawful entrant. It does not address duties arising merely from being a neighbor or co-occupant of premises sharing a common driveway, nor does it discuss obligations to maintain areas ‘immediately adjacent’ to a shared accessway. The duty here is explicitly tied to landowner status and control over the tort-causing condition, not to the kind of neighbor/co-occupant shared-driveway relationship described in the proposition.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 153.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. … This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … [A] landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’”}

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.raw_text: Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973) (landowner/occupant owes lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care in all the circumstances)
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.proposition: Defendant further owed Plaintiff a duty, as a neighbor and co-occupant of the premises sharing a common driveway, to exercise reasonable care in maintaining conditions immediately adjacent to the shared driveway in a reasonably safe condition for foreseeable use by Plaintiff.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Mounsey v. Ellard is a concurring discussion about abolishing the invitee/licensee distinction and moving to a general reasonable-care duty by occupiers toward lawful entrants. It does not specifically address duties between neighboring co-occupants or obligations to maintain areas immediately adjacent to a shared driveway for a neighbor’s foreseeable use. While Mounsey supports a broad duty of reasonable care by land occupiers to lawful visitors, it does not itself establish the more specific neighbor/co-occupant shared-driveway duty stated in the proposition.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors.

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 56–57 (1983) (standard of reasonable care under all circumstances)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: The question of whether Defendant’s conduct meets the standard of reasonable care is one for the fact-finder.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: This excerpt is a dissent focused entirely on the sufficiency of evidence of causation and whether the defendants were entitled to directed verdicts. It does not discuss who (judge vs. jury) decides whether conduct meets the standard of reasonable care, nor does it articulate the general principle that reasonableness is a fact question for the fact-finder. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff had the burden of proving “that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.” Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). ... In my opinion the plaintiff failed to introduce sufficient evidence to warrant a finding that action or inaction of the defendants was the proximate cause of her injury, and the defendants were entitled to directed verdicts and judgments in their favor.

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696\u2.raw_text: Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696–97 (2000) (negligence requires duty, breach, causation, damages)
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696\u2.proposition: The question of whether Defendant’s conduct meets the standard of reasonable care is one for the fact-finder.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss who decides whether the defendant’s conduct met the standard of reasonable care; instead, it resolves the negligence claims at the summary judgment stage on the ground that plaintiffs failed to produce evidence of causation. The court explicitly declines to reach even the duty question and nowhere states that the reasonableness of the defendant’s conduct is a question for the fact-finder. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the cited proposition.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696\u2.relevant_excerpt: "Because the plaintiffs have failed to meet their burden on the issue of causation, we need not decide whether they presented sufficient evidence to show that the defendant owed a duty of care to them sufficient to survive the defendant’s motion for summary judgment. See St. Germaine v. Pendergast, 411 Mass. 615, 622-623 (1992) (employer of independent contractor not liable for harm caused to another by independent contractor’s negligence, unless employer retained some control over manner in which work was done)."

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637, 639 (1996) (foreseeability and scope of duty)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: Plaintiff’s prior complaints about the Ladder falling on her car provided Defendant with actual notice of the specific risk.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: The quoted passage is a concurrence focused on causation and foreseeability in general; it does not mention any prior complaints by the plaintiff, notice, or ladders, nor does it address actual notice of a specific risk. Instead, Justice Lynch is agreeing only that the injuries were not within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm, which is contrary to a claim that prior complaints established actual notice of that very risk. Thus, this citation does not support the proposition about actual notice from prior complaints.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: "I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641."

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.raw_text: Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320–21 (2002) (proximate cause and foreseeability)
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.proposition: 'Proximate cause' under Massachusetts law requires that the harm be a foreseeable result of the negligent conduct.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely defines proximate cause in Massachusetts negligence law in terms of foreseeability, stating that proximate cause depends on whether the injury was a foreseeable result of the negligent conduct. The court contrasts proximate cause with mere factual causation and emphasizes that proximate cause (i.e., foreseeable result) is limited by policy and pragmatic judgment. This directly supports the proposition that proximate cause requires that the harm be a foreseeable result of the negligent conduct.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.relevant_excerpt: “In addition to being the cause in fact of the injury, the plaintiff must show that the negligent conduct was a proximate or legal cause of the injury as well. See Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254 (1935). Whether negligent conduct is the proximate cause of an injury depends not on factual causation, but rather on whether the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct. Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978).”

Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.raw_text: Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978)
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.proposition: 'Proximate cause' under Massachusetts law requires that the harm be a foreseeable result of the negligent conduct.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames proximate cause in terms of foreseeability of the intervening third-party act and applies that test to determine whether the defendant’s negligence can be a legal cause of the plaintiff’s harm. The court quotes and adopts the classic Massachusetts formulation that the original negligence remains a culpable and direct cause if the intervening act "ought to have been foreseen," and then holds that the jury could find the seaman’s conduct and resulting injury reasonably foreseeable. This aligns directly with the proposition that proximate cause under Massachusetts law requires that the harm be a foreseeable result of the negligent conduct.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.relevant_excerpt: “The general rule is that ‘[t]he act of a third person, intervening and contributing a condition necessary to the injurious effect of the original negligence, will not excuse the first wrongdoer, if such act ought to have been foreseen. The original negligence still remains a culpable and direct cause of the injury. The test is to be found in the probable injurious consequences which were to be anticipated….’ … Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable.”

FMR Corp. v. Boston Edison Co., 415 Mass.raw_text: FMR Corp. v. Boston Edison Co., 415 Mass. 393, 395–96 (1993) (negligence action for property damage and related loss)
FMR Corp. v. Boston Edison Co., 415 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts law permits recovery for property damage and consequential economic loss caused by negligence.
FMR Corp. v. Boston Edison Co., 415 Mass.case_name: FMR Corp. v. Boston Edison Co.
FMR Corp. v. Boston Edison Co., 415 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely reaffirms Massachusetts’ economic loss rule: purely economic losses are not recoverable in negligence absent personal injury or property damage. By negative implication, the court recognizes that where there *is* property damage, consequential economic losses are recoverable in negligence. The court distinguishes the plaintiffs’ claims as involving “solely economic” damage and rejects them on that basis, thus supporting the proposition that property damage plus related economic loss is compensable.
FMR Corp. v. Boston Edison Co., 415 Mass.relevant_excerpt: 1. Negligence claims for economic damage. We have recently affirmed that purely economic losses are unrecoverable in tort and strict liability actions in the absence of personal injury or property damage. Garweth Corp. v. Boston Edison Co., ante 303 (1993). We see no reason to abandon this longstanding rule.

Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc.,.raw_text: Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc., 45 Mass. App. Ct. 461, 462–63 (1998) (recovery of cost of repairs and related losses)
Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc.,.proposition: Massachusetts law permits recovery for property damage and consequential economic loss caused by negligence.
Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc.,.case_name: Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc.
Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc.,.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on the measure and availability of damages under Massachusetts General Laws c. 21E, not on a general common-law rule about negligence. While the court does reference common-law property damage principles to interpret § 5, it ultimately disallows the claimed property damages and notes that no evidence of consequential losses such as lost rental value was offered. The case therefore does not affirmatively establish that Massachusetts law permits recovery of consequential economic loss for property damage caused by negligence; it is a statutory environmental contamination decision and not a negligence damages precedent.
Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: “At common law, the measure of damages to real property is dependent upon whether ‘the injury is permanent’ or ‘reasonably curable by repairs.’ … When the injury is permanent, the appropriate measure of damages is diminution of value … When the injury is temporary, that is, ‘reasonably curable by repairs, the expense of repairs, if less than the diminished market value, is the measure of recovery.’ … Our interpretation reserves to § 5 not only actions for permanent injury but also actions for the incidents of cleanup such as related restoration and repair work and lost rental value suffered during the cleanup and repair period.”

Schleissner v. Provincetown, 29 Mass. Ap.raw_text: Schleissner v. Provincetown, 29 Mass. App. Ct. 834, 835–36 (1991) (cost of reasonable repairs is appropriate measure of damages for property damage)
Schleissner v. Provincetown, 29 Mass. Ap.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a plaintiff in a property damage negligence action may recover the reasonable cost of repairs and other reasonably necessary and foreseeable consequential expenses.

Trinity Church in the City of Boston v..raw_text: Trinity Church in the City of Boston v. John Hancock Mut. Life Ins. Co., 399 Mass. 43, 48–49 (1987) (damages should place plaintiff as nearly as possible in position she would have been in absent negligence)
Trinity Church in the City of Boston v..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a plaintiff in a property damage negligence action may recover the reasonable cost of repairs and other reasonably necessary and foreseeable consequential expenses.
Trinity Church in the City of Boston v..case_name: Trinity Church in the City v. John Hancock Mut. L. Ins.
Trinity Church in the City of Boston v..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly adopts cost of repair/restoration as the measure of property damage where diminution in market value is unavailable, and requires that such repair costs be reasonable and reasonably necessary in light of the damage. While the case focuses on structural restoration costs for special-purpose property rather than listing “consequential expenses” in detail, its reasoning and approval of “replacement or restoration costs” and “expenditures to restore or to replace to predamage condition” as damages necessarily encompasses reasonably necessary and foreseeable consequential repair-related costs. Thus it supports the proposition under Massachusetts law for property damage negligence actions, especially where market value is not an adequate measure.
Trinity Church in the City of Boston v..relevant_excerpt: “Replacement or restoration costs have also been allowed as a measure of damages in other contexts where diminution in market value is unavailable or unsatisfactory as a measure of damages…. Where expenditures to restore or to replace to predamage condition are used as the measure of damages, a test of reasonableness is imposed. Not only must the cost of replacement or reconstruction be reasonable, the replacement or reconstruction itself must be reasonably necessary in light of the damage inflicted by a particular defendant…. Trinity is entitled to be compensated for the reasonable costs of restoring the church to the condition it was in prior to the Hancock excavation.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B and 6C.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B and 6C, Plaintiff is also entitled to prejudgment interest on her damages from the date of commencement of this action.
